final_answer:
The humor or satire in this image stems from the juxtaposition between the pedestrian signal and the context at the intersection. 

On the left, the words “YES,” appear above pedestrian signals showing both red (stop) and green (go) figures, suggesting a functioning and conventional traffic system that guides pedestrian behavior.

On the right, the word “BUT” introduces a contradiction. The image shows an empty intersection with a distant red light, indicating that even though the pedestrian signal might be saying "go," the context makes it irrelevant or ironic since there’s no traffic to watch for or cross against.

This creates a humorous or satirical commentary on how signals and rules can sometimes be out of place or redundant, highlighting the absurdity when systems continue to function despite a lack of necessity.
